It can take decades for a country to build up a name as a good place to do business, and the U.S.
ranks among the best.
But some economists say its reputation could be challenged if President-elect Trump makes good on threats to rip up international agreements.
NPR's Jackie Northam reports.
Having a good reputation is a huge economic plus for any country - and one the U.S.
has enjoyed for a long time.
The U.S.
is consistently among the top five, the top 10 countries in the world in terms of the environment for doing business.
And this is mostly because of the rule of law and the transparency of government decision.
That's Simeon Djankov, the senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics and formerly the chief economist at the World Bank.
He says America's solid reputation could quickly disappear if President-elect Trump carries through with some of his campaign promises.
He points to the Paris climate accord, signed by world leaders a year ago.
Djankov says there was an underlying expectation in the global business community that an international contract would be honored when the next U.S.
president took office.
And suddenly, the president-elect says, well, I don't like this agreement.
I may not abide by it.
These businesses are thrown into panic since they already may have spent maybe hundreds of thousands or even millions of dollars abiding by this new regulation.
Now it's for nothing, so to speak.
Scuppering such agreements can erode trust with international investors, says Ray Fisman, a professor of economics at Boston University.
If there's one thing that deters investment, it is uncertainty.
You don't quite know what you're in for if you consider doing business in the U.S.
It's still unclear whether there will be a bright line between Trump's business dealings and the White House.
His children have sat in on meetings with world leaders and advisers.
Trump has said his sons would run his companies while he's president.
But he could still make money off his name used on hotels across the world.
We should not forget that perceptions are important.
Alejandro Salas is a director at Transparency International, which produces an index every year looking at the impact of perceived corruption on international investment in more than 160 countries.
Salas says the higher level of corruption, the less attractive a country is to investors - and vice versa.
The U.S.
ranked 16th last year.
Salas says that may change because Trump appears to disregard many rules and regulations.
The fact that there could be so much conflict of interest - the fact that he says, as far as the conflict of interest, laws don't apply to the president - that's very dangerous.
Salas says the American system of checks and balances will help hold the government accountable.
For now, investors will give the new president time and latitude to settle into the job.
And the stock market is going gangbusters.
Jackie Northam, NPR News.
The capture of the Jordanian pilot is a reminder that the U.S.-led air campaign against ISIS has been going on for nearly five months.
And to talk further about how that's been going and what's changed since the campaign started we turn to Eric Schmitt.
He covers national security and terrorism for The New York Times.
Welcome to the program.
Thank you.
So you just returned from a visit to the U.S.S.
Carl Vinson - that's the aircraft carrier the U.S.
uses to launch some of these airstrikes.
Give us a sense of how often the strikes are happening.
Sure, there are about a hundred aircraft that fly off the aircraft carrier every day, about 20 of those are actually flying what they call strike missions into either Syria or Iraq.
That's about a quarter of the overall total that the U.S.-led coalition is conducting every day.
These are, obviously, aircraft that are flying from a number of European countries as well as about half a dozen countries in the Middle East.

And so what they're doing is they're either looking for targets that had been preplanned - they're going to strike a warehouse, for instance, or a bunker that they've identified - but most often what they're doing is they're supporting the Iraqi troops on the ground and any trouble they get into.
If they get into a firefight, these are aircraft that can come down and give what's called close air support - drop bombs on the enemy in support of the Iraqi troops on the ground.
That's the majority of the missions that are being flown right now.
So between Iraqi forces and the U.S.-led coalition, what progress has been made in destroying the weapons capabilities of ISIS?
Well, ISIS was able to assemble a pretty vast arsenal.
They had a number of weapons already before they swept into northern Iraq in June.
And when they did that they overtook a number of Iraqi depots and took a lot of equipment that the Iraqi army had that the United States has provided them.
We're talking about armored personnel carriers, artillery, a lot of small arms rifles and ammunition.
A lot of this stuff was carted back to Syria where they'd then - the ISIS has been using it in their campaign there.
A lot of it continues to be used in the ISIS campaign in Iraq against the Iraqi security forces, including the peshmerga, which is the militia in Kurdistan in the northern part of Iraq.
You know, we heard that U.S.

military officials say that they do not believe that the Jordanian jet was shot down, but when you talk about that weapons arsenal, I mean, what dangers do coalition planes face when they strike ISIS?
Well, and in talking to the pilots aboard the Vinson, they are very concerned about the weapons.
It can be anything from basically turning up machine guns - high-powered machine guns - up in the air if you're flying really low, which is dangerous for helicopters.
For these kind of fighter jets that are typically flying in fairly high altitude it's much harder.

But ISIS has been able to either buy or acquire a number of surface-to-air missiles, some of which are shoulder-fired, heat-seeking missiles, and they've already downed three or four Iraqi helicopters.
And it's enough of a concern for the American pilots that they fly well above 20,000 feet in carrying out their bombing missions, which is outside the range of most of these missiles.
So it's a threat, but mostly only if you come down, you know, in the lower altitudes.
Number one question that I love asking them is - where did you get your news?
Well, the Red Cross says their policy is that you can go in and out of this facility, and I think the Red Cross really is trying to do everything differently here.
I mean, just from the moment you walk in, you see all these cots lined up in a perfect, perfect row, and the air conditioning, the lights and the way they're treating them.
I think this is going to be the opposite of the Superdome.
And--are you still with me?
Yes, we're still with you.
Well, I'm about to walk on the upper tier here of the Astrodome and get our first look of the floor of the Astrodome, and wow.
I saw this last night when they were setting up the cots, and remember I said it was perfect order?
Mm-hmm.
Well, now refugees have descended, and it's a patchwork.
It looks like people have just piled up tons of belongings on each and every cot.
So many open cots, but everybody's claiming their cots while they still can.
They probably learned that in the Superdome.
Oh, there's a kids' play area in what would be the end zone.
It looks like there's some--looks like construction tubes.
I don't know if they should be playing on that, but they've roped it off, and the kids look like they're in a playground.
They're running around.
There's a lot of people now who have orange--I'm sorry--yellow shirts which clearly they've been given here.
I see people lining up to get--it looks like towels.
I heard from someone that they were getting clothes, that they could get all the beverages and food that they wanted.
But it's quite a scene because it's, you know, more than the size of a football field, and it looks about, you know, maybe a fifth full now.
Is it still--I know it's been years since they hosted any sporting events there.
It's still set up as a football stadium?
Well, there's no--I mean, it's in the widest configuration possible, so there's no goalposts, there's no--it's concrete flooring.
But there's still the banners hanging--the championship banners hanging, and there's still these--I don't know if you remember the Astro colors of red, orange, yellow.
Vividly.
Vividly.
Yeah, you can't forget that sort of look of the '70s that the stadium had.
So it still has that.
And the amazing thing is that there are--there's a glass ceiling to the Astrodome.
A lot of people may not know this because they covered it up for baseball; it was too bright.
But now it's like having a giant sunroof.
Like I said, it's the opposite of the Superdome because the light is just streaming in here, and it's like being outside.
But, of course, I think the temperature here is like 58 degrees.
Well, obviously, they're anticipating the arrival of more thousands that will warm it up just a tad, I suspect.

Well, some of the refugees said they were warned that there were dozens and dozens of more buses arriving just today, and so they were very--they were a little--starting to get a little concerned that they needed to grab their cots and a little worried that they would--you know, I mean, they're a little afraid of overcrowding.
You can understand that after their experience.
Obviously, one of the concerns also will be security.
Evidence of much of that in--is there much evidence of that?
Oh, it's a very secure facility, and in fact, the sheriff was saying earlier that there had been a couple of incidents which involved having their officers having to move on individuals.
But the mayor of Houston wanted to stress that, like--that these facilities will have a ton of security.
But he wanted to say, `It's not like we're treating these people as criminals.
There just happens to be a criminal element whenever you put 25,000 people in one place.
But he did stress that there would be strict, you know, in and out access, that they would be searching people when they went in and that kind of thing.

Obviously people in the Superdome will have--when they arrive in Houston will still be desperate to find relatives, friends, some of whom still may be en route from New Orleans, some of whom may be still in the city, some of them, who knows where?
Yeah, and one of the sadder things is outside the gates of the Astrodome, a lot of family members have shown up here, family members who live in Texas, looking for any word of people.

Now they're kept from this facility, and they have no access to the people in and out, and so it's a little sad to hear their story, you know, and the last time they talked to their family members and desperate to know if the family members were in here.

So they haven't released a list; they don't know who's here.
